transcriptText:
In this video, Thierry gives a clear demonstration of different tempo/ cadence while swinging clubs to a metronome.

Swinging at a moderate speed will help your Indian clubs swinging skills, and avoid you bad habits. The rhythm of the swings should remain constant through the whole arc, no sudden acceleration and deceleration, which results in jerky movements, and a lack of flow.

Using a metronome or a drum loop in 4/4 time will ensure you control the swings and maintain a constant cadence from start to finish. This is important in the beginning stages, as sometimes if can look as the clubs are controlling the swinger.

For those into Persian meels, one criteria of judgement for competitions is sticking to the beat/ cadence set by the drummer.

Our brains love rhythm repetitive patterns and  beats.

Rhythm is important for all athletic endeavors, not just dancing!

If you can't time your actions, you will miss the ball/ punch /fill in the blanks...

As for Tom Burrows record, after consulting with Conor Heffernan, Ph.D. (assistant Professor in Physical Culture and Sport Studies | Trustee of the British Society of Sport History) he could not provide answers as to the counting.

We both suspect that a heart shaped swing would have been counted as 2 revolutions, and possibly each hand counted separately. That would still be a crazy pace to maintain for one hour with 1,5kg clubs, let alone 100 hours!

By the way, after having judged kettlebell sport and kettlebell marathons events, I feel for the poor judges!

To learn step by step how to swing Indian clubs,

WHY YOU SHOULD SWING INDIAN CLUBS

Gently mobilizes the shoulders, elbows and wrists and improve range of motion

Strengthens the shoulder girdle and grip ( muscles and connective tissues) in its full range of motion

Consists of compound movements in multiple planes

Provides low impact cardiovascular exercise

Assists recovery from intense training

Improves the 3 pillars of physical literacy (body control , locomotion and object control)

It is fun and you forget you are training.

The rhythmic and repetitive patterns are highly meditative and calm the nervous system, like meditation.

Cross crawl exercises and other challenging moves improve learning capacity and stimulate neurogenesis, the creation of new brain cells.

❂ HEROIC SPORT | AN ANCIENT SPORT

Our clubs are easily adjustable, which is a modern twist on the ancient traditional Indian clubs used to train Tamil and Persian warriors.

Indian clubs were used in Europe and USA for remedial gymnastics in the 18th and 19th century, by pioneers of physiotherapy.

❂ READY TO LEARN MORE?

All our educational material has been tested and structured since 2010, in a way that is easy for anyone to learn from home.

Best regards from Thierry & Ron
